articles.title: We can repurpose retired coal plants to produce green energy
articles.summary: Piles of dirt can cheaply store renewable energy as heat – and that stored energy can reactivate the machinery of retired coal power plants, letting them provide backup power for the electricity grid
articles.content:
Piles of dirt can cheaply store renewable energy as heat – and that stored energy can reactivate the machinery of retired coal power plants, letting them provide backup power for the electricity grid

A derelict coal power plant at the abandoned Indiana Army Ammunition Plant The American Explorer/Shutterstock

Dozens of retired coal-fired power plants could find new life providing backup or emergency power for the electricity grid – except this time without the need for fossil fuels. They could instead rely on heat energy stored in dirt.

The concept involves creating a huge dirt pile near a coal plant and placing industrial heaters inside. During the grid’s low-demand periods, these machines would convert cheap electricity into heat, which would remain stored within the dirt at a temperature of about 600°C. During times of high power demand, the heat could be transferred out of the dirt via pipes of heated liquid.

The coal plant’s turbine blades and connected generator could then turn that heat into backup energy. The heat would transform water into steam, which would spin the turbine blades to produce electricity. “Instead of taking the coal to heat up the water to produce the steam, you use the heat from this energy stored in the dirt,” says Ken Caldeira at Stanford University in California.

Energy storage like this is necessary to supplement renewable power sources, such as wind and solar, which only provide energy intermittently. And dirt is cheaper, more abundant and more widely available than other types of long-term energy storage, such as lithium batteries or hydrogen fuel.

“The really exciting part is specifically the low energy capacity cost, because it’s so much cheaper than other energy technologies,” says Alicia Wongel at Stanford University.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

However, this approach could have other costs. “Reducing piping and electrical costs are essential in such systems and may be a challenge,” says Andrew Maxson at the Electric Power Research Institute, a non-profit research organisation headquartered in California.

Most dirt includes naturally heat-resistant materials, such as silicon dioxide and aluminium oxide, which make it “pretty robust to heating”, says Austin Vernon at Standard Thermal in Oklahoma. His start-up is looking to commercialise this “heat battery” technology for repowering retired coal power plants, especially at sites with nearby solar or wind power sources.

In the US, such retired coal facilities are abundant – nearly 300 coal-fired plants retired between 2010 and 2019 alone, and an additional 50 gigawatts of coal plant capacity is expected to reach the typical retirement age of 50 years by 2030. Although the Trump administration has attempted to delay coal plant retirements, coal’s share of US electricity production peaked in the late 2000s, unable to out-compete cheaper natural gas and renewables.

Christian Fong at the Rocky Mountain Institute, a research organisation based in Colorado, is optimistic about the idea of giving defunct coal plants a new purpose. “This provides a way for local communities to participate in the clean energy transition by providing jobs and additional tax revenue to help displace the retirement of the coal plant,” he says.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses an innovative and sustainable approach to repurposing retired coal plants for green energy production, which contributes positively to climate action and renewable energy solutions.
articles.personality_title: Retired coal plants could store and deliver green energy using heated dirt
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many coal-fired power plants have been shut down as countries shift toward cleaner energy. However, finding ways to use this existing infrastructure for renewable power storage and backup is a challenge.

**What happened** – Researchers have proposed using large piles of dirt near retired coal plants to store heat energy generated by renewable sources during low electricity demand. Industrial heaters would warm the dirt to about 600°C, storing the energy as heat. When electricity demand is high, the heat is released to produce steam that spins the coal plant’s turbines, generating power without burning coal.

**Impact** – This method offers a low-cost, widely available way to store energy, addressing the problem of renewables like wind and solar not producing power consistently. Dirt is abundant and cheaper than batteries or hydrogen fuel, making this heat storage approach potentially more affordable and scalable.

**What's next step** – Further studies and pilot projects will test how well heated dirt can store and release energy in real conditions. If successful, more retired coal plants could be converted to support renewable energy grids, providing backup power without fossil fuels.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Using heated dirt to store renewable energy could repurpose retired coal plants as affordable backup power sources for cleaner electricity grids.

Des chauffages industriels réchaufferaient la terre à environ 600°C, stockant ainsi l'énergie sous forme de chaleur. Lorsque la demande électrique augmente, cette chaleur est libérée pour produire de la vapeur qui fait tourner les turbines, générant de l'électricité sans brûler de charbon.

**Impact** – Cette méthode offre un stockage d'énergie peu coûteux et largement disponible, répondant au problème de l'intermittence du vent et du solaire. La terre est abondante et moins chère que les batteries ou l'hydrogène, rendant ce stockage thermique potentiellement plus accessible et évolutif.

**Prochaine étape** – Des études et projets pilotes vont tester l'efficacité du stockage et de la libération de chaleur dans la terre en conditions réelles. Si cela fonctionne, davantage de centrales à charbon arrêtées pourraient être converties pour soutenir les réseaux renouvelables, fournissant une énergie de secours sans combustibles fossiles.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Utiliser la terre chauffée pour stocker l'énergie renouvelable pourrait transformer les centrales à charbon arrêtées en sources d'énergie de secours abordables pour des réseaux électriques plus propres.
articles.personality_title_es: Plantas de carbón retiradas podrían almacenar y suministrar energía verde usando tierra calentada
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchas plantas de energía a carbón han cerrado mientras los países avanzan hacia energías más limpias. Encontrar formas de reutilizar esta infraestructura para almacenamiento y respaldo renovable es un reto.

**Qué sucedió** – Investigadores propusieron usar grandes montones de tierra cerca de plantas de carbón retiradas para almacenar calor generado por fuentes renovables en momentos de baja demanda eléctrica. Calentadores industriales elevarían la temperatura de la tierra a unos 600°C, almacenando la energía como calor. Cuando la demanda eléctrica aumenta, el calor se libera para producir vapor que hace girar las turbinas, generando electricidad sin quemar carbón.

**Impacto** – Este método ofrece una forma económica y ampliamente disponible de almacenar energía, resolviendo el problema de la intermitencia del viento y el sol. La tierra es abundante y más barata que baterías o hidrógeno, haciendo este almacenamiento térmico potencialmente más accesible y escalable.

**Próximo paso** – Se realizarán estudios y proyectos piloto para probar la efectividad del almacenamiento y liberación de calor en la tierra en condiciones reales. Si tiene éxito, más plantas de carbón retiradas podrían convertirse para apoyar redes renovables, proporcionando energía de respaldo sin combustibles fósiles.

**Resumen en una frase** – Usar tierra calentada para almacenar energía renovable podría reutilizar plantas de carbón retiradas como fuentes económicas de energía de respaldo para redes eléctricas más limpias.

articles.title: Gorillas seek out old female friends even after years apart
articles.summary: A study in Rwanda reveals the significance of a social connection between female mountain gorillas.
articles.content:
Gorillas seek out old female friends even after years apart

5 hours ago Share Save Victoria Gill Science correspondent, BBC News Share Save

Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund Female gorillas appear to maintain their social relationships for many years

The relationships built up between female mountain gorillas are more important than previously understood, new research from Rwanda suggests. It shows that when one of these social great apes moves into a new group, she will seek out and join another female she already knows. Scientists based the research on 20 years of data covering multiple groups of gorillas in Volcanoes National Park, in Rwanda. The scientists found that even when two females had been apart for many years, a newly arrived gorilla would still try to join a female she had formed a previous connection with.

Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund Gorilla social groups occasionally come together, allowing females to form connections with individuals in other groups

The findings, published in the Royal Society Journal Proceedings B, show how important the relationship between two individual females is in gorilla society. "Scientifically, I don't know if I can talk about 'friendship'," explained lead researcher Victoire Martignac, a PhD researcher form the University of Zurich. "But we're showing here that these same sex relationships really matter." Moving into different groups is key in shaping the animals' social structure. It's something that both males and females do - females will sometimes move several times throughout their lives. This dispersal, as it's known, plays a role in avoiding inbreeding, spreading gene diversity and shaping social relationships. "In the wild it is very important," explained Ms Martignac. "But it's extremely hard to study, because once individuals leave a group, it's hard to keep track of them."

Working in partnership with the Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund, at a field site that has been monitored since 1967, Ms Martignac and her colleagues were able to track those movements. Poring through decades of information on the animals' lives, the scientists followed the "dispersals" of 56 female mountain gorillas - examining which new group they chose to join and why. The gorillas avoided groups that had males they were likely to be related to, but the presence of females they knew also "mattered a lot", Ms Martignac explained. The females gravitated towards their "friends", even if the animals had been apart for many years. They would often gravitate to a group with females they had grown up with, even if that was many years ago. They also sought out individuals with whom they had made a social connection - perhaps played and interacted with - recently.

Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund Female-female relationships are much more important to gorilla society than previously understood
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a positive and heartwarming scientific discovery about social bonds among female mountain gorillas, emphasizing the importance of long-lasting social connections in wildlife. This kind of insight can inspire curiosity and appreciation for animal behavior and conservation efforts.
articles.personality_title: Female mountain gorillas maintain long-lasting social bonds
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Female mountain gorillas live in social groups where relationships shape their lives. When gorillas move between groups, studying their social ties is difficult because they are hard to track once they leave.

**What happened** – A new study from Rwanda, using 20 years of data from Volcanoes National Park, found that female gorillas seek out and join females they already know when they move to a new group. Even after years apart, these gorillas reconnect with previous companions.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that female mountain gorillas maintain important social bonds over long periods, which play a key role in how their groups form and interact. It also helps explain their behavior related to avoiding inbreeding and spreading genetic diversity.

**What's next step** – Researchers hope to continue monitoring these gorillas to better understand how these strong social connections affect their survival and group dynamics over time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Female mountain gorillas prioritize long-term social relationships by reconnecting with familiar companions even after years apart.

articles.personality_title_es: Las gorilas montesas mantienen lazos sociales duraderos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las gorilas montesas viven en grupos sociales donde sus relaciones influyen en su vida. Cuando las gorilas se mueven entre grupos, es difícil estudiar sus vínculos sociales porque pierden seguimiento tras salir.

articles.title: Countries gather to thrash out deal on 'plastic crisis'
articles.summary: The world's nations are hoping to sign the first global plastic treaty to limit plastic pollution.
articles.content:
Countries gather to thrash out deal on 'plastic crisis'

1 day ago Share Save Esme Stallard Climate and science reporter, BBC News Share Save

Nipah Dennis/Bloomberg/Getty Images

Plastic production has exploded in the last century - to some it has been a miracle product while to others it is a pollution nightmare. Scientists have estimated that there are nearly 200 trillion pieces floating in the world's oceans, and this could triple if no action is taken. In 2022, countries agreed to develop a legally binding global treaty to cut the waste and the harmful chemicals some plastics contain - but after two years no agreement has been reached. On Tuesday, the world's nations meet again at a UN conference in Geneva - could they finally agree how to curb the plastic excesses?

Why is plastic such a valuable product?

Human societies have used plastics that occur naturally in the environment for hundreds of years, in the form of rubber, horn and shellac. But the 20th Century brought the explosion of synthetic plastics, made from processing fossil fuels. The material's versatility, strength and heat-resistant properties has lent itself to thousands of uses, from sewage pipes to life-saving medical equipment, to clothing. It has become ubiquitous in a short time without understanding its full impact, explains Dr Alice Horton, research scientist at the National Oceanography Centre. "Proportional to life on earth, plastics have been around for no time at all, there are people alive that weren't using plastics as children. I think that's what makes this quite a concerning material," said Dr Horton. "It has exploded in such a way that we are using it in every application in our lives and yet we are suddenly realising there may be problems with it."

How are plastics impacting our planet?

Levels of plastic production have grown exponentially over the last few decades. In 1950 two million tonnes was produced, by 2022 that had risen to 475 million tonnes. Although plastic can be reused, the cost and availability of recycling infrastructure means very little is. About 60% of all plastics are single use and just 10% are estimated to be recycled, according to analysis in Nature. Plastic has been shown to accumulate in the marine environment where it poses particular problems for wildlife who can ingest it. "They can confuse it as food, which then harms their internal organs and also can lead to fatalities, because of digestion difficulties," said Zaynab Sadan, global plastics policy lead at WWF. She said they could also become entangled in discarded fishing gear or plastic packaging that has entered the ocean from sewage systems.

When it enters the environment, most plastic breaks down into smaller and smaller pieces - known as microplastics. They have been found across all geographical ranges, from the deep sea to mountain tops, and across all living systems ever tested. Research is continuing to understand the full impact, with different species faring better than others. But Dr Horton from the National Oceanography Centre warns there is a threshold where animals will start to be harmed. "When we [get] accumulation of plastic in tissues we start seeing inflammation, cell damage, hormonal changes. Things that are not outright going to kill an organism but likely to have this accumulative, long-term effect whereby they get weaker and weaker, and sicker and sicker, and either become diseased or die," she explained.

Are plastics harmful for us?

Plastics are a "grave, growing and under-recognised danger" for human health, according to a new expert report. The Lancet Countdown estimated that health-related disease and death from the "plastic crisis" is responsible for at least $1.5tn (£1.1tn) a year in health-related damages.

Gerald Anderson/Anadolu/Getty Images Informal waste workers - common in many countries - are at risk of burns, cancer and stillbirths according to the Lancet

These impacts can range from air pollution from the production of plastic, through to elevated risk of cancer, respiratory illnesses and miscarriages from plastic contamination in our bodies. Plastics contain more than 16,000 chemicals such as dyes and flame retardants, some of which are toxic and cancer-causing. Despite the growing body of evidence of the hazards of plastic, the Lancet report highlights that there is a lack of transparency as to what is in most products. Just a quarter of plastic chemicals have data on their impact, but of those tested 75% were found to be "highly hazardous".

What are countries trying to agree?

In 2022, countries agreed a global treaty was needed in two years to tackle the issue. That deadline passed in December 2024, after five rounds of negotiations, with no treaty having been signed. On Tuesday, more than 170 nations will meet again to try to get a deal over the line. The main issues they are trying to get agreement on include: Targets on cutting the production levels of single-use plastics

Bans on some of the most harmful chemicals in plastic

Universal guidance on the design of plastic products

Financing of this effort Products that have to meet consistent design standards can help to improve recycling, save costs and reduce the demand for virgin plastics, Rob Opsomer, executive lead of plastics and finance at the Ellen McArthur Foundation, which co-convenes the Business Coalition for a Global Plastics Treaty, told the BBC. "So, to give you one example, a drinks bottle, if it is coloured, the value of what you can get from it if you sell the recycled material is half the value of a clear, uncoloured bottle," he explained. Nearly 100 countries, including the UK, are calling for an "ambitious" treaty which would include a commitment to limit production levels. But there has been strong opposition from a group of oil-producing nations including Russia and Saudi Arabia who want the talks to focus not on producing less, but recycling more. Demand for oil in global energy and transport systems is expected to peak in the next few years as countries move to greener technologies. This could leave plastic as one of the few growth markets for the oil industry. Any efforts to limit production could pose short term economic damage to the petrostates. But for those users of plastics not having clear, global regulations is costing them. "It is a fundamental risk. Businesses don't want packaging with their brand name on it to be littering the streets and our oceans," said Mr Opsomer. He said there was also the cost for businesses of having to comply with hundreds of new standards globally every year on plastics. The Business Coalition, which includes some of the biggest global users of plastic such as Nestle and Unilever, is calling for governments to introduce coordinated taxes on their businesses to help pay for the cost of recycling and cleaning up plastic waste.

What can you do to reduce plastic waste?

Single-use plastic is the biggest contributor to plastic waste in the environment, and most of our daily consumption of this comes from food packaging. You can take a reusable container or cup if you are getting a takeaway, and when food shopping consider taking a reusable sealed bag to weigh your fruit and vegetables. It is estimated that more than a quarter of microplastics in the environment come from car tyres. For those that are able, walking and cycling to the local shops or sharing car journeys with friends or neighbours can help. And avoid plastics that break down to microplastics more easily - such as chewing gum and glitter. There are many non-plastic alternatives still available which means you can keep having fun at festivals.

articles.personality_title: Nations meet to finalize historic global treaty on plastic pollution
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Plastic use has grown rapidly since the 20th century, becoming essential in many products but also creating significant pollution. Scientists estimate nearly 200 trillion plastic pieces currently float in oceans, posing risks to nature and health. In 2022, countries agreed to work on a global treaty aimed at reducing plastic waste and harmful chemicals.

**What happened** – After two years of discussions, the United Nations hosted another conference in Geneva where countries gathered to negotiate the terms of this treaty. The goal is to create a legally binding agreement that limits plastic pollution worldwide.

**Impact** – This treaty would be the first global effort to control plastic pollution through international law. By setting shared rules, it can reduce the amount of plastic waste entering ecosystems, protect marine life, and address health concerns linked to plastics. It marks a clear step from voluntary actions to collective responsibility.

**What's next step** – If countries reach an agreement, the treaty will move to formal adoption and then implementation phases. Governments will need to create national plans to meet treaty goals. This may encourage innovation in plastic use, recycling, and alternatives to harmful materials.

**One-sentence takeaway** – World leaders are close to signing the first global treaty to limit plastic pollution and reduce its environmental impact.

articles.title: Mystery of billions of sea-star deaths solved at last
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 05 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02442-9Experiments identify a bacterium as the cause of sea-star wasting disease, which has devastated populations along the western coast of North America.

articles.reasoning: The article reveals a scientific breakthrough in identifying the cause of a devastating disease affecting sea stars, which is a positive step toward conservation and ecosystem recovery. This discovery can lead to solutions that help restore marine biodiversity, offering hope for environmental health.
articles.personality_title: Scientists identify cause of sea-star wasting disease after years of mystery
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For years, sea stars along the west coast of North America have been dying in huge numbers due to a condition called sea-star wasting disease. This has dramatically reduced their populations and affected coastal ecosystems.

**What happened** – In August 2025, researchers published experiments that pinpointed a specific bacterium as the cause of this disease. The study involved controlled lab tests that showed the bacterium infects sea stars, leading to their characteristic wasting symptoms.

**Impact** – Identifying the bacterium is a key breakthrough because it moves scientists closer to developing treatments or management strategies. With a clear cause known, conservation efforts can be better directed to protect and restore sea-star populations, which play important roles in marine environments.

**What's next step** – Researchers will now focus on finding ways to control or eliminate the bacterium in the wild. They may develop treatments for affected populations and monitor the disease’s spread to prevent future large-scale die-offs.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have finally identified the bacterium behind sea-star wasting disease, paving the way for targeted efforts to protect these vital marine animals.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques identifient la cause de la maladie dévastatrice des étoiles de mer après des années de mystère
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis des années, des étoiles de mer meurent en grand nombre sur la côte ouest de l’Amérique du Nord à cause d’une maladie appelée syndrome de dépérissement des étoiles de mer. Cela a fortement réduit leurs populations et affecté les écosystèmes côtiers.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En août 2025, des chercheurs ont publié des expériences qui ont identifié une bactérie spécifique responsable de cette maladie. Les tests en laboratoire ont montré que cette bactérie infecte les étoiles de mer, provoquant leurs symptômes de dépérissement.

**Impact** – Identifier cette bactérie est une avancée majeure car cela permet aux scientifiques de développer des traitements ou des stratégies de gestion. Avec la cause connue, les efforts de conservation peuvent mieux protéger et restaurer ces populations, qui jouent un rôle important dans l’environnement marin.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont désormais chercher des moyens de contrôler ou d’éliminer la bactérie à l’état sauvage. Ils pourront développer des traitements pour les populations touchées et surveiller la propagation de la maladie afin d’éviter de nouvelles mortalités massives.

**En une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont enfin identifié la bactérie responsable du syndrome de dépérissement des étoiles de mer, ouvrant la voie à des actions ciblées pour protéger ces animaux marins essentiels.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos identifican la causa de la enfermedad que afecta a las estrellas de mar tras años de misterio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante años, las estrellas de mar a lo largo de la costa oeste de América del Norte han muerto en grandes cantidades debido a una condición llamada enfermedad del desgaste de las estrellas de mar. Esto ha reducido drásticamente sus poblaciones y afectado los ecosistemas costeros.

**Qué ocurrió** – En agosto de 2025, investigadores publicaron experimentos que identificaron una bacteria específica como la causa de esta enfermedad. Los estudios de laboratorio demostraron que esta bacteria infecta a las estrellas de mar, provocando sus síntomas característicos.

**Impacto** – Identificar la bacteria es un avance clave porque acerca a los científicos a desarrollar tratamientos o estrategias de manejo. Conociendo la causa, los esfuerzos de conservación pueden enfocarse mejor para proteger y restaurar las poblaciones de estrellas de mar, que tienen un papel importante en los ecosistemas marinos.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores ahora buscarán formas de controlar o eliminar la bacteria en la naturaleza. Podrían desarrollar tratamientos para las poblaciones afectadas y monitorear la propagación de la enfermedad para evitar futuras muertes masivas.

**En una frase** – Los científicos finalmente identificaron la bacteria detrás de la enfermedad del desgaste de las estrellas de mar, abriendo el camino para esfuerzos dirigidos a proteger a estos animales marinos vitales.
